loans.name: Ramon Aristides

texts.es:
Ramón es un hombre de 45 años, es soltero, vive en la ciudad de Ica, él es una persona muy amable, trabajador y entusiasta, que tiene un gran deseo de superación; lamentablemente por falta de recursos económicos y por la necesidad de trabajar para solventar sus gastos, Ramón no pudo estudiar una carrera profesional, pero gracias a su esfuerzo se encuentra se estudiando la carrera técnica de computación, en sus ratos libres le gusta distraerse viendo televisión y en algunas ocasiones come un riquísimo Pollo a la brasa para compartir con su familia.
Por iniciativa propia, con mucho empeño y dedicación, Ramón trabaja como vigilante, brindando servicios de seguridad en una fábrica de su ciudad, él trabaja todos los días por un aproximado de 12 horas y cree que le va bien por su buen desempeño y por el trato amable que brinda a los demás.  
Ramón se encuentra muy agradecido con los prestamistas Kiva, ya que gracias a la ayuda brindada podrá realizar la compra de una computadora, la cual le servirá de mucho para poder hacer sus trabajos y practicas académicas, así pues Ramón seguirá trabajando y esforzándose para lograr su gran sueño de tener su casa propia.
texts.en:
Ramón is a 45 year old man who is single and lives in the city of Ica. He is a very friendly person, who is hard working and enthusiastic. He has a great desire to exceed himself. Unfortunately due to lack of economic resources and the need to work in order to pay his bills, Ramón was not able to study a professional career, but thanks to his dedication he is currently studying a technical computing career. In his free time he likes to disconnect watching television and sometimes he cooks a delicious grilled chicken dish to share with his family.

On his own initiative, with hard work and dedication, Ramón works as a security guard, offering a security service to a factory in his city. He works every day for approximately 12 hours and thinks things are going well thanks to his good performance and friendliness towards others. 

Ramón is very grateful for the Kiva loans, as thanks to the help received he will be able to buy a computer. This will help him do his work and academic practice. Ramón will continue working and making an effort to fulfil his dream of having his own house.

loans.use: to buy a computer.

loans.name: Dagoberto

texts.es: Dagoberto de 63 años habita al sur de la ciudad donde se dedica ala preparación y venta de comidas rápidas y frituras, negocio que inició hace 2 años después de haber leído un libro sobre aptitud mental positiva, el cual lo inspiró a realizar una actividad diferente a su profesión y fue así como se inclinó en ofrecer el servicio de alimentos, directamente entre vecinos transeúntes y referidos por este mercado. Su meta es abrir otro punto de atención para generar empleos para sus familiares que necesitan ingresos  y quiere tener esa oportunidad de apoyar su bienestar. En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará materias primas e insumos como salsas, embutidos, cárnicos, lácteos y  harina de trigo, compra con la cual ganará descuentos por realizarla en un mayor volumen que el acostumbrado y esto aumentará su capacidad productiva, para impactar nuevos mercados.
texts.en:
Dagoberto is 63 years old and lives in the south of the city where he makes a living preparing and selling fast and fried foods. He started this business two years ago after reading a book about positive mental attitudes, which inspired him to carry out a different activity to his profession. That was how he began in his food service, directly through commuting neighbours and indirectly through this market.

His goal is to open a service point in order to generate employment for his family members who need the income and he would like to have this opportunity to support their well being. Presently he is requesting a loan, his first loan cycle with the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, in order to buy raw materials and supplies such as sauces, cold meats, meat and dairy products, and wheat flour. With this purchase he will earn discounts by buying in bulk and this will increase his productive capacity and help enter new markets.

loans.use: to buy raw materials and supplies such as sauces, cold meats, meat and dairy products, and wheat flour.

loans.name: Manal

texts.en: Manal is a 38-year-old conservative woman and she has asked her husband to appear in the photo in her place. The couple have two sons and two daughters. Her husband works in a factory during the day and in the evenings he sells birds from home. Now Manal wants to support her husband and buy more types of birds to sell, so she has applied for this loan.

loans.use: buy more types of birds to sell

loans.name: Ne'ma

texts.en:
Ne’ma is 35 years old and the married mother of seven sons and daughters. She is a farmer who receives a small monthly salary. Ne’ma started selling blankets at home in addition to her work as a farmer. 

Ne’ma is requesting a loan to purchase new blankets and bed covers in different sizes in addition to what she has.

loans.use: to purchase new blankets and bed covers

loans.name: Las Azucenas De Pueblo Nuevo Group

texts.es: Anayeli tiene 19 años de edad es una chica que aún vive con sus papás y estudia la preparatoria abierta los sábados para tener tiempo para ayudar en casa con las labores del hogar. Platica que es la primera vez que pide un crédito y que las amigas de su mamá la animaron para que entrara al grupo Las Azucenas de Pueblo Nuevo. Le comentaron que le habían puesto ese nombre al grupo porque en su casa su mama tiene un jardín muy grande con flores de azucenas. Ana, como es conocida, puso hace un año una tienda de abarrotes en su casa para poder trabajar en la semana y estar al pendiente de su casa y de sus hermanitos ya que sus papas salen a trabajar y también para ayudarse a pagar las colegiaturas de la preparatoria. Ana pide a VisionFund un crédito para surtir un poco mas de todo lo que vende como huevo, leche, papel higiénico, aceite para cocinar, pañales, azúcar, sal, huevo, atún, servilletas, refrescos, galletas y un poco de dulces para vender de todo un poco, platica que los días sábados va a una tienda de su población donde le vende por mayoreo y le dan precios bajos, dice más adelante quiere vender carnes frías y meter diferentes lácteos, dice que terminando de estudiar la prepa quiere meterse a estudiar para educadora ya que sería uno de sus más grandes logros. Las otras integrantes del grupo se llaman Alma Isabel, Gabriela, Marisela, Fabiola, María Isabel, Irma, Adelina y Jarintzi ellas invertirán en la compra de colchas para vender, en la compra de insumos para elaborar pan, para surtir tienda de abarrotes, comprara pollo muerto para venderlo por kilos, para la compra de cosméticos y perfumería para vender y para surtir zapato para dama y caballero para su venta.
texts.en:
Anayeli is 19 years old.  She is a young woman who still lives with her parents and studies in an “open” high school (an alternative adult school) on Saturdays in order to have time to help at home with the household chores.  She says that it is the first time that she has asked for a loan and that friends of her mother encouraged her to enter the group “Las Azucenas de Pueblo Nuevo” (Pueblo Nuevo Easter Lilies).  They commented to her that they had given that name to the group because in her home her mother has a very big garden with lily flowers.  

Ana, as she is known, put a grocery store in her house about a year ago in order to be able to work during the week and keep an eye on her home and on her younger siblings since her parents go out to work and also to help pay the tuition fees of the high school.  Ana is requesting a loan from VisionFund to stock a little bit more of everything that she sells like eggs, milk, toilet paper, oil for cooking, diapers, sugar, salt, eggs, tuna, napkins, soft drinks, cookies and some candy in order to sell a little bit of everything.  She says that on Saturdays she goes to a store in her town where they sell wholesale and give her low prices.  She says that later on she wants to sell cold cuts and put in different dairy products.  She says that upon finishing her high school studies she wants to go into studying to be an educator because it would be one of her greatest achievements.  

The other members of the group are Alma Isabel, Gabriela, Marisela, Fabiola, María Isabel, Irma, Adelina y Jarintzi.  They will invest in the purchase of bedspreads to sell, in the purchase of supplies to make bread, to stock a grocery store, to buy chicken to sell by the kilo, to buy cosmetics and perfumes to sell and to stock shoes for women and men to sell.

loans.use: to buy eggs, milk, toilet paper, oil for cooking, diapers, sugar, salt, tuna, napkins, soft drinks, cookies and some candy.

loans.name: Nadhir

texts.en:
Nadhir is a 28 year old young man who lives in Sana`a, Yemen. He decided to start his own business and opened a grocery store. He has been operating his store for many years and employs two people. 

Nadhir has fought against adversity his whole life. However, he is a friendly person and always has a smile for his customers. He wants to increase the store's sales so he can prosper financially and offer his family a better future.

In order to increase sales at his store, Nadhir plans to buy more products and offer more variety for his customers. He doesn't have enough capital right now to expand his inventory.  He is requesting a youth loan of 500,000 YER from AMB. The loan will allow him to buy basic products such as rice, sugar, flour, beans and soft drinks to sell at his store, which will increase sales. He hopes that the extra income that he will generate can provide a better quality of life for his family.

loans.use: to buy basic products such as rice, sugar, flour, beans and soft drinks to sell at his store.

loans.name: Mesaadeh

texts.en: Mesaadeh is 56 years old.  She is a mother to five children, both sons and daughters. In order to help support her family, she sells clothes and makeup products from her home. She is applying for a loan to purchase clothing for the spring season and more makeup products.

loans.use: to bring more spring collection of clothing

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 23-year-old single man who lives in Sana`a, Yemen. For the past two years, he has been operating a book shop. Ali started his business with limited capital and now has some regular customers and is quite preferred in the area because he always strives to keep a variety of products in his store so that his customers will always find what they are looking for. Lately, he’s noticed that competition has become quite fierce. As this business is his main source of income, he always wants to stay one step ahead of his competition. 

Ali is requesting a 300,000 YER youth loan from AMB to buy stationary products such as pens, books, notebooks, dolls, and other items to help keep his clientele and attract new customers. In the future, he hopes to attain better living conditions and be able to maintain his business for a long time.

loans.use: to buy stationary products such as pens, books, notebooks, dolls, and other items

loans.name: Baydaa

texts.en:
Baydaa is a 33-year-old married woman whose husband is a private-sector employee. She started a business selling accessories and later started making pickles to order. 

Baydaa is requesting a loan to buy vegetables to make more pickles. She wants to expand her pickle business and make greater quantities of pickles. In the future, Baydaa hopes to open a store to sell fruits, vegetables, and pickles.

loans.use: to buy vegetables to make pickles

loans.name: Sariya

texts.en:
Sariya is a 54-year-old woman with two children. She is a conservative woman and asked her daughter, Azhar, to appear in this photo instead. 

Sariya is requesting a loan to help her pay next semester's fees for Azhar, who is a university student.

loans.use: to support her daughter and pay upcoming semester fees

loans.name: Balina Group

texts.en:
Hellen’s group has 12 farmers and is located in Kakamega South District. Hellen is pictured on the right of Balina Group with her hand raised. Hellen is pictured amongst the 3 men and 9 women of her group. She will receive input loans capable of planting ½ an acre with sorghum, millet, and maize. Hellen first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2012 Long Rains season and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Hellen joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer and access to the best input prices.

Hellen described her harvest as excellent last year as a One Acre Fund farmer and hopes for another good year in the 2013 Long Rains season. She plans on using future profits from the harvest to send her children to school and invest in cows. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Hellen’s group will receive 6 acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Msoso A Group

texts.en:
Lydia’s group has 20 farmers and is located in Kakamega South District. Lydia is pictured on the right of Msoso A Group with her hand raised. Lydia is pictured amongst the 3 men and 17 women of her group. She will receive input loans capable of planting ½ an acre with sorghum, millet, and maize. Lydia first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2011 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Lydia joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food for the family and to have a better harvest.

Prior to joining One Acre Fund, Lydia was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize per ½ acre, but after joining One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2012, she was able to harvest 5 bags per ½ acre! She hopes that her profits from the 2013 Long Rains season can be used to send her children to school and perhaps invest in another business. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Lydia’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 10 acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet and sorghum

loans.name: Shianda Group

texts.en:
Shianda Group is located in Kakamega South District. It is a group of 10 women and 2 men led by Catherine pictured on the right with her hand raised. She is receiving an input loan for ½ an acre of maize, millet and sorghum cultivation. Catherine first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2012 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Catherine joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food for her family and to use the increased profits to send her children to school.

Catherine described her harvest as very good last year, but believes she can have an even better one this year. She hopes that her profits from the 2013 Long Rains season can be used to send her children to school and assist the needy. Catherine’s group members will each receive input loans of ½ acre during the 2013 Long Rains season. In total, they will receive inputs for 6 acres of maize, millet and sorghum.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet and sorghum.

loans.name: Musembe Group

texts.en:
Patrick is a member of Musembe Group in Kakamega South District. He is pictured with 10 One Acre Fund farmers, two women and eight men. Patrick is standing on the right with his hand raised. He is receiving a loan to cultivate 1/2 an acre of maize, millet, and sorghum. Patrick joined One Acre Fund during the 2011 Long Rains season and is now enrolling in the 2013 Long Rains season. Patrick joined One Acre Fund so that he could gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer and specialize in modern production.

Patrick reports that before One Acre Fund, he was able to grow about 7 bags of maize per 1/2 acre, but with his One Acre Fund loan during Long Rains 2012, he harvested 9 bags per 1/2 acre. He plans to use the money that he earns from his next harvest to send his children to school and to save for the future. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Patrick’s group members will take loans to cultivate 1/2 acre each. In total, this group will receive loans to use on 5 acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Gilivazio

texts.en:
Gilvazio is 52 years old and comes from Nyarushanje – Rukungiri District. He is married with eight children.

Gilvazio has a tree planting business in order to protect and preserve the environment. He has been running this for the past four years. He has applied for his second loan from UGAFODE Micro finance Limited (MDI) to enable him to buy more seedlings for planting trees to grow into mini forests.Gilvazio owns nursery beds for the different kinds of trees which he sells to different categories of people depending on their choice to earn income.
 
After facing a hard time generating income to meet his family and children's needs, he then put much emphasis on this project of planting and buying of trees around his home area. 
He hopes his family's standard of living will greatly improve in the near future since now he is comfortably able to take care of his family of eight children and his wife.
He thanks UGAFODE Microfinance Limited (MDI) for the financial assistance rendered all this time.

loans.use: To buy seedlings for planting.

loans.name: Fawzia

texts.en: Fawzia is a 41 year old woman.  She is a mother to four children, both sons and daughters. She sells clothes and towels from home to help her husband support the family. Fawzia is applying for a loan to purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Kdaf

texts.en:
Kdaf is a 26-year-old married man who lives in Hodeidah, Yemen. He works as cleaner in the public sector and earns a low salary. Kdaf is respectful man. He intends to buy construction supplies for his house, but the amount he has saved is not enough to buy what he needs. 

Kdaf is requesting a 70,000 YER youth loan from AMB to buy construction supplies to improve his living standards.

loans.use: to buy construction supplies to improve his living standards

loans.name: Lubov

texts.en:
Lubov's business is going well with thanks to her previous loan, which she used to purchase seasonal children's clothing. The diversified assortment of goods attracted more customers and thus, brought more profits to her business.

This time Lubov is asking for a loan to purchase Spring clothing for children and teenagers. Her considerable experience and low prices have enabled Lubov to gain many repeat clients, stable profits and hope for the future.

loans.use: to purchase seasonal clothing to sell

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna is the married parent of five children. She operates a business selling vegetables in the Philippines and earns additional income from farming rice. Edna works hard to support her family. She has been sustaining her business activities through her previous four loans from NWTF.

Edna is requesting a 13,000 PHP loan to buy additional vegetables to sell. In the future, she hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving money to expand her business and support her children's studies.

loans.use: to buy vegetables to sell

loans.name: Eleonor

texts.en:
Eleonor is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business selling rice in the Philippines. She has had her business for eight years, and also earns an income from raising chickens. Eleonor has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF.

Eleonor is requesting a 30,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell. In the future, she dreams of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase rice to sell

loans.name: Wepesi Group

texts.en:
Jenifer is a member of Wepesi Group in Kakamega South District. She is pictured among 11 One Acre Fund farmers, 7 women and 4 men. Jenifer is standing on the right with her hand raised. She is receiving an input loan for ½ acre of maize, millet, and sorghum cultivation. Jenifer first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2012 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Jenifer joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer and access the best input prices. 

Jenifer reports that before One Acre Fund, she was able to grow about 4 1/2 bags of maize per acre, but with her One Acre Fund input loan during Long Rains 2012, she harvested 9 1/2 bags per acre! She plans to use the money that she earns from her next harvest to send her children to school and repair her home. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Jenifer’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 5.5 acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet and sorghum

loans.name: Oliver

texts.en:
Oliver is a 33-year-old, married woman with three children, living in Bundibugyo, Uganda. She is a farmer and mainly grows cocoa. With the proceeds, she has been able to expand her cocoa plantation and pay school fees. The seasonal nature of the business affects her income flows, while her desire is to venture into the retail shop business. 

Being the good mother that she is, she desires to see all her children attaining degrees, as minimum qualification. Oliver intends to use the loan to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Haraka Group

texts.en:
Judith is pictured on the right with her hand raised amongst her Haraka Group members. The 23 of them, 17 women and 6 men, are farmers in Kakamega South District. Farming inputs will be delivered to Judith on credit, consisting of the necessary materials to plant ½ acre of maize, millet and sorghum. Judith first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2007 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Judith joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer and grow enough food for the family.

Prior to joining One Acre Fund, Judith was only able to harvest 2 bags of maize per 1 acre, but last year, she was able to harvest 18 bags per 1 acre! She plans to use the money that she earns from her next harvest to send her children to school and invest in a new cow. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Judith’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 11.5 acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Kassim

texts.en:
Kassim is 40 years, deals in the maize trade, and also has a retail shop. He would like to get money to add stock to his business in order to make ends meet. 

His dream is to give his family a better life by taking his children to good schools, ensuring that they get the best education, as well as living in modest accommodations. 

His challenge is weather, and competition from people of the same business. He is hardworking and honest.

He is confident that the partnership will be maintained, since he promises to meet his repayments as scheduled. He is a hard-working man.

loans.use: To buy a stock of beans and corn.

loans.name: Mariam's Group

texts.en:
Mariam's group is comprised of two hard-working women. Mariam is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kaliro, in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past three, Mariam has been working hard to manage her clothing sales business. She sells clothes for both children and adults. 

To help expand her business, Mariam has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes for sell, which will help Mariam to improve her standard of living and generate greater profits. Mariam hopes that in the future she will be able to boost the business. 

Mariam is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more clothes for sell

loans.name: Beatrice's Group

texts.en:
Beatrice's group is comprised of four hard-working women. Beatrice is 20 years old and lives in the town of Hima in the Fortportal region of Uganda. She has three children who are all currently in school. For the past five years, Beatrice has been working hard to manage the small hotel that she owns. 

To help expand her business, Beatrice has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy material to put in her small hotel, which will help Beatrice to generate greater profits and lead to increased returns and expansion of the hotel. Beatrice hopes that in the future she will be able to add more money to the business. 

Beatrice is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy material to put in her small hotel,

loans.name: Lineath

texts.en:
Lineath, age 16, manages a retail store, where she sells such items as sugar, flour, and rice. She has been operating her business for two years. She lives in the town of Hima in the Fortportal region of Uganda. 

To help expand her business, Lineath  has requested a loan in the amount of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to improve the business and will allow her to buy new items for the store, such as cooking oil. This will help Lineath generate greater profits and help bring in more income. Lineath hopes that in the future she will be able to continually improve her business. 

Lineaath is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to improve the business and allow her to buy new items for the store, such as cooking oil

loans.name: Norah's Group

texts.en:
Norah's group is comprised of 2 hard-working women. Norah is 18 years old and lives in the town of Hima in the Fortportal region of Uganda. For the past 11 months, Norah has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells maize, rice and coffee. 

To help expand her business, Norah has requested a loan of 600000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to look after the family and add more commodities in the shop to be sold to her clients at a good price. This will help Norah to generate greater profits and enlarge the business. Norah hopes that in the future she will be able to add to the business. 

Norah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to look after the family and add more commodities in the shop to be sold to her clients at a good price

loans.name: Gerina's Group

texts.en:
Gerina's group is comprised of 2 hardworking women. Gerina is 23 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children who are all currently in school. For the past 3 years, Gerina has been working hard to manage her fruit business, which sells passion fruits. 

To help expand her business, Gerina has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy a fridge and will help Gerina to generate greater profits and increase the income level of the family. Gerina hopes that in the future she will be able to start another  business. 

Gerina is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy a fridge

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en:
Anthony is 50 years old and lives in Pakwach, Uganda. He is married and has 6 children; with 5 of them currently in school. For the past 6 years, Anthony has been working hard to manage his stall, which sells flour. 

To help expand his business, Anthony has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to improve on the business and buy more produce such as maize flour to sell. It will also help Anthony generate greater profits and help generate income. Anthony hopes that in the future he will be able to expand the business. 

Anthony is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Anthony who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more product like maize flour for his stall.

loans.name: Proscovia

texts.en:
Proscovia is a 32-year-old lady and a mother of three children; she also takes care of two widows who are wives of her late brothers who died in a fire accident last year.  She provides them with all basic needs and pays the children’s tuition from the small income she earns from her poultry business.
She started this business in 2009 to meet the growing needs of the family. She struggled to start up a poultry business from the little savings she had, plus a little help from her relatives.
She has managed the poultry business because it doesn’t involve lots of skills. She has a dream of growing her small poultry business to a medium sized farm in her village so as to increase on her productivity and income level. Her major challenge is lack of sufficient capital to boost her business and at the same time meet the many needs of her extended family.
Neighbors applaud Proscovia as a very hardworking, determined and dedicated woman with a bright future.

loans.use: To buy more chicks as well as poultry feed

loans.name: Manuella

texts.en:
Manuella is a 30-year-old lady and a resident in on of the city slum areas. She has 2 children and both attend school. She deals in selling clothes and shoes in her boutique, which she started in 2011 so as to improve on her daily income.

Manuella’s customers are mostly ladies around the area. She has requested a loan of 500,000 for paying tuition for her daughter in elementary school. 
Manuella faces challenges of inadequate capital, competition, and other problems that hinder her business's performance. She feels that most of these challenges are due to the fact that her business operates on a small scale.
   
Manuella has a dream of seeing her business grow so that it can be self-sustaining. She also wishes that then, it will help her take better care of her children.

loans.use: To pay tuition for her daughter

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie is 50 years old and married with four children. For the past 22 years, she has been running a general store in the Philippines. She also earns an income from buying and selling fish. Elsie works hard to provide for her family and has borrowed and repaid 18 previous loans from NWTF. 

Elsie is requesting an 11,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase stocks to sell such as soap, canned goods, eggs, noodles, and other items. In the future, she aspires to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase soap, canned goods, eggs, noodles, and other items

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store business in the Philippines. She has been operating her business for three years and also earns an income from making ice-candy. Fe has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF.

Fe is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase stocks to sell such as noodles, canned goods, eggs, spices, and other items. In the future, she dreams of saving enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase noodles, canned goods, eggs, spices, and other items

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna is 36 years old and married, with three children, of whom two are in school. Myrna works very hard to provide for them.

Myrna runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 12,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to buy additional stocks of canned goods, soap, noodles, rice, etc. to sell.

Myrna has been in this business for one year. In the future, Myrna would like to save enough money, so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks of canned goods, soap, noodles, rice, etc. to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy organic manure

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is a 50-year-old widow with three children, one of whom is at the university. She also takes care of two relatives who are orphans, for whom she pays tuition and provides their other basic necessities.

Betty’s challenge is lack of enough income to take care of her financial needs, as she gets her major income from the small subsistence farming that she does at her home. She does this in order to see her children finish school and have a better life.
Her dream is to finish her house, such that she can occupy it and then stop renting. She could then use the money she has been using for rent to increase her earnings and also be able to let out some part to raise more income.
But Betty has had a challenge of lack of enough cash to finish up her house. This is the reason she has resorted to borrowing, and hopes with the loan she will be able to finish it and see her dream come true.

Betty is a hardworking woman who has seen her children grow and some finish school from all the struggles she has gone through since her husband died.

loans.use: to buy construction materials for completion of her residential house.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy groceries to sell.

loans.name: Damali

texts.en: Damali is a single mother with three children; two of whom attend school. She is solely responsible for their well being and upkeep.. She is directly involved in buying agriculture produce like maize and cassava which she processes to get flour and then sells to the public. Damali has been engaged in this business for the last six years as evidenced by the photos taken with the loans officer. She has been able to buy a piece of land on which she wants to build a house in future such that she can stop renting which has proved expensive for her. However, this cannot be done with business income because if she did so, her small capital would all be consumed and therefore she had to apply for a loan of three million Uganda shillings to stock more agricultural produce.Damali's dream is to build a big shopping arcade within the town  centre if she gets funds. In the photo is Damali (L) and the ugafode credit officer (R).

loans.use: to buy more dry agricultural produce

loans.name: Mahd

texts.en:
Mahd is 20 years old and single. He has two brothers and two sisters. 

Mahd is a second-year university student majoring in economics. He works a part-time job to support himself. Mahd is applying for a loan to help pay for his fees next semester.

loans.use: to pay for his next semester fees.

loans.name: Josita

texts.en:
Josita is a married parent with three children. She has a business selling dried fish in the Philippines and also earns additional income from raising pigs and goats. Josita works hard to support her family and has been sustaining her business activities through 17 previous loans from NWTF.

Josita is requesting a 26,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy additional boxes of dried fish to sell. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy dried fish to sell

loans.name: Mary Joy

texts.en: Mary Joy is married and works hard to support her family by running a blacksmithing business in the Philippines. She is requesting a loan for PHP 26,000 from NWTF to buy more of the materials, including iron and wood, she needs to run her business. She has been in this line of work for six years and hopes to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy supplies for a blacksmithing business.

loans.name: Raylen

texts.en:
Raylen is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a motorcycle transport business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 30,000 through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to purchase spare parts for her motorcycle transport business.

Raylen has been in this business for seven years. Raylen earns more income from buying and selling fish.

Raylen has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts, with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for her motorcycle transport business.

loans.name: Elvis

texts.en:
Elvis is 56 years old and married with three children.

She earns a living by raising livestock in the Philippines. Elvis is borrowing 16000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional livestock to sell.

Elvis has been raising livestock for 5 years. She earns additional income from buying and selling dried fish.

She is working tirelessly towards the attainment of her dream: to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional livestock to sell

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan works hard to support her family. Susan is married and has a food vending business in the Philippines.

Susan requested a 15000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy ingredients and supplies for her food vending business.

Susan has been in this business for 10 years now.

In the future, Susan would like to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy ingredients and supplies for her food vending business.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Yolanda works hard to support her family.

She has a fish vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling vegetables. Yolanda is borrowing 18000 PHP through NWTF to purchase additional fish to sell.

Yolanda has sustained her business activities through her past 15 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell.

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Nenita works hard to support her family.

She has a direct-selling business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from ready-to-wear and reflexology. 

Nenita is borrowing PHP 20,000 through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to purchase more items to sell, like lotion, soap, and lipstick for her direct-selling business.

Nenita has been sustaining her business activities through her past 13 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money, so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell, like lotion, soap, and lipstick.

loans.name: Qais

texts.en:
Qais is a 30 year old man who is single. He has one brother. After his father passed away, he and his brother were in charge of supporting the family. 

In response, Qais started a medium-sized food store.  He wants to purchase more goods to sell, which is why he is applying for a youth loan.

loans.use: to purchase more goods to sell

loans.name: 08-Pt2-06-Phú Sơn2 Group

texts.en:
Liễu has a service business providing housing rentals. She is requesting a loan to purchase material to build a house for renting.

Liễu is 49 years old and she is married, with four children. Liễu is the group leader of the 08-Pt2-06-Phú Sơn2 solidarity group, which consists of four members. She lives and works in Thanh Hoa City, an urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with one dependent. Three other children are grown up.

In 2011, Liễu joined the Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women to improve her business. Liễu has successfully repaid three loans from the Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women.

Liễu has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. The main hardship that Liễu faces in her business is the lack of capital. With her business profit, Liễu hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, for her children to find good jobs, and for her business to do well.

loans.use: to purchase material to build a house for renting.

loans.name: 08-Pt2-07-Phú Sơn 2 Group

texts.en: Mrs. Minh earns a living by raising poultry and cattle, and is requesting this loan to buy more livestock to add to her herd. She is 43 years old, married and the mother of two children. She also leads a four-person loan group which is called 08-PT2-07-Phú Sơn2 Solidarity. She lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, a urban part of Thanh Hoa province. In 2011, Minh joined the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business, and has successfully repaid three previous loans. She has been in her current line of work for seven years and her main business challenge is a shortage of capital. Minh hopes to earn enough money to have a healthy and happy family, educate her children so they can get good jobs, and build a new house.

loans.use: to buy poultry and cattle to raise and resell.

loans.name: Juvylyn

texts.en:
Juvylyn works hard to support her family. Juvylyn is married and has a fishing/fish-vending business in the Philippines.

Juvylyn requested a PHP 20,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to purchase wood and bamboo for the repair of her fishing boat.

Juvylyn has been in this business for eight years now. In the future, Juvylyn would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to purchase wood and bamboo for the repair of her fishing boat.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita is married, with five children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Margarita is 63 years old and has three children who are in school.

Margarita has a fishing business in the Philippines. Margarita requested a PHP 12,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to purchase additional equipment for her fishing business.

Margarita has been in this business for 30 years. In the future, Margarita would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional equipment for her fishing business.

loans.name: Mireya Del Socorro

texts.es:
Mireya de 37 años de edad, soltera, madre de tres hijos de 18, 7,18 años, originaria de León, lugar que está ubicado en la zona de occidente del país. Lamentablemente por falta de recursos económicos, no pudo cursar una carrera universitaria; ella se caracteriza por ser una persona, trabajadora, responsable, de bunas costumbre, con ganas de superación personal, lo cual lo ha demostrado en sus créditos anteriores en el cumplimientos de sus pagos en tiempo y forma.
Gracias a su esfuerzo, tiene por actividad económica la venta de mercadería en general, que consisten en vender pantalones, camisas, vestidos, short, camisetas, ropa interior, cosméticos, perfumes, artículos escolares. Actividad a la que dedica unas 10 horas diarias,  y la realiza de forma ambulante y por encargo. Ella diariamente carga un bulto de unos 20 kg ofreciendo sus productos. Actividad que la desempeña con mucho gusto, porque es su forma de vida y la de sus hijos. El objetivo del crédito es invertir en capital de trabajo y surtir su negocio en la compra y venta de mercadería, para que en un futuro no muy lejano pueda obtener mejores ingresos. Mireya del Socorro agradece la ayuda que los inversionistas kiva les brindan a personas de escasos recursos y países pobre como es Nicaragua para tener un medio de trabajo digno.
texts.en:
Mireya, 37 years old, is a single mother of three children, 18, 7, and 18 years of age. She is originally from León, a place that is located in the western part of the country. Unfortunately, because of the lack of economic resources, she could not study at a university. She is characterized as a hard-working, responsible person with good habits and a desire for personal self-improvement, which she has demonstrated in her previous loans in her on-time and complete payments.

Thanks to her effort, she sells general merchandise. This consists of selling pants, shirts, dresses, shorts, t-shirts, underwear, cosmetics, perfumes, and school items. She works about 10 hours a day on foot and through orders. She carries a load of about 20 kilograms when offering her products. She performs this activity with pleasure because it is her and her children’s way of life.

The objective of the loan is to invest it in the capital of her work and supply her business with merchandise, from which in the near future she will be able to obtain a better income. Mireya del Socorro gives thanks for the help that the Kiva lenders provide to people of limited resources and from poor countries like Nicaragua to have a dignified means of working.

loans.use: to invest in her work and supply her business with merchandise such as pants, shirts, dresses, shorts, t-shirts, underwear, cosmetics, perfumes, and school supplies.

loans.name: 08-Pt2-05-Phú Sơn2 Group

texts.en: Ms. Sáu earns a living by running a food stall and restaurant where she sells groceries. She is requesting a loan to buy candy, milk, biscuits and sugar to sell to her customers. She is 64 years old, single and the mother of two children. She also leads a six-person loan group called 08-PT2-05-Phú Sơn2 Solidarity. Her children are grown so she has no dependents living with her in Thanh Hoa city, a urban section of Thanh Hoa province. In 2011, Sáu joined the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her  business. She has successfully repaid three previous loans, and has been in her current line of work for more than 10 years. The main hardship that she faces in her business is a lack of capital. Her goals for the future are to be healthy and happy, to build a new house, and for her business to do well.

loans.use: to buy candy, milk, biscuits and sugar to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Virginia Elena

texts.es:
La Sra. Virginia vive Guayaquil. Ella empezó trabajando para una empresa de confección luego decidió comprase sus propias máquinas y comenzar con su negocio de confección de ropas para todo tipo de tallas.
Trabaja sola, todo el día, en su casa tiene el negocio en donde cose blusas, pantalones, interiores, de todo un poco.
Cada día le pide a Dios por su bienestar y que la libre de cualquier enfermedad a ella y a su hijo que ya es mayor de edad, es una mujer soltera, su esposo la abandono dejándola sola con su hijo, debido a esto ella siguió adelante para así poder darles un mejor vivir.
Con el préstamo quiere poder incrementar con más telas, máquinas e hilos para así poder coser con mayor facilidad y hacer más cosas que los clientes le piden. Además consiguiendo mas maquinas puede darles trabajo a demás personas para que le faciliten el trabajo y así poder obtener más ganancias para un mejor vivir para su familia.
texts.en:
Virginia lives in Guayaquil. She started working for a dressmaking company, then decided to buy her own machines and start her business making clothing for all sizes. She works on her own, all day long. She has her business in her home, where she sews blouses, pants, underwear—a little bit of everything. Every day she asks God for her well-being and to keep her and her adult son free from any disease.

She is a single mother, as her husband abandoned her, leaving her alone with her son. Because of this, she has kept going so that she can give them a better life. 

With the loan she wants to expand, with more fabric, machines and thread, so that she can sew more easily and make more things that her customers request. Besides getting more machines, she can give work to other people, enabling them to earn more and provide a better living for their families.

loans.use: To buy fabric, machines, and thread.

loans.name: Rodema

texts.en:
This is Rodema, who has previously taken out and repaid a loan for PHP 20,000 which she used to buy spare parts and accessories and for the maintenance of her vehicle. The earnings this loan generated helped her meet her personal, household and business expenditures. She is requesting a new loan, for PHP 25,000, to buy spare parts and maintain her vehicle. The profits she earns will help her meet her daily needs. She is grateful for the help she is receiving from Kiva lenders. Her goal for the future is to acquire additional vehicles so that she can give her children a good life and a hopeful future. She meets up with her co-fellowship members* to share stories of her work every week, and draw strength and inspiration from her religion.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who study religion, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for spare parts and the maintenance of her vehicle.

loans.name: 08-Pt2-01-Phú Sơn2 Group

texts.en:
Mai has a retail business, selling groceries. She is requesting a loan to purchase biscuits, candy, and fruit to sell.

Mai is 28 years old and she is married, with two children. She is the leader of a five-member group, the 08-Pt2-01-Phú Sơn2 solidarity group. 
She lives with two dependents and works in Thanh Hoa city, an urban area in Thanh Hoa province.

In 2011, Mai joined the Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women to improve her business. Mai has successfully repaid three loans from the Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women.

Mai has been involved in this business for five years. The main hardship that Mai faces in her business is the lack of capital. With her business profit, Mai hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, to buy land of her own, and for her business to do well.

loans.use: to purchase biscuits, candy, and fruit to sell.

loans.name: 08-Pt2-02-Phú Sơn2 Group

texts.en:
Ms. Hương has a retail business selling dry food. She is requesting a loan to purchase biscuits, candy, milk and sugar to resell.

Hương is 33 years old and single with two children.

Hương is the group leader of the 08-PT2-02-Phú Sơn2 solidarity group, which consists of five members. She lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, an urban area in the Thanh Hoa province.

In 2011, Hương joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Hương has successfully repaid three loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Hương has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. The main hardship she faces in her business is a lack of capital.

In the future, Hương hopes that her family will be healthy and happy and that her children will do well in school. She also hopes her business will do well.

loans.use: to purchase biscuits, candy, milk and sugar to resell.

loans.name: Rodina

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Rodina works hard to support her family.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and she also earns additional income from fattening pigs. Rodina is borrowing PHP 9,000 through NWTF to buy a fishing net, bamboo and other materials for the repair of her fishing boat for her fishing business.

Rodina has been sustaining her business activities through her past loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy a fishing net, bamboo and other materials for the repair of her fishing boat.

loans.name: Marisol

texts.en:
Marisol is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 25,000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional items like soap, sugar, noodles, spices, and canned goods to sell in her general store.

Marisol has been in this business for ten years. She earns additional income as a food vendor.

Marisol has sustained her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional items like soap, sugar, noodles, spices, and canned goods to sell.

loans.name: Paul Angelo

texts.en:
This is Paul Angelo. He previously accessed a 17,000 PHP loan that he used to buy spare parts and accessories and to pay for the maintenance of his tricycle unit. His earnings were a big help in paying for the education of his child and for his personal, household and business expenditures. He has been in this business for seven years now.

He would like to apply for another 18,000 PHP loan to buy spare parts and to pay for the maintenance of his tricycle unit. The profits from this business will definitely help him to sustain his daily needs and the educational expenses of his child. He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart.

Paul Angelo dreams of expanding his business and dreams of having a good life. He meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group comprises 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to buy spare parts and pay for the maintenance of his tricycle unit.

loans.name: Rose Marie

texts.en:
Rose Marie works hard to support her family. She is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines.

Rose Marie has requested a PHP 17,000 loan through NWTF to buy materials for the maintenance of her fishing boat.

Rose Marie has been in this business for five years now.

In the future, Rose Marie would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy materials for the maintenance of her fishing boat.

loans.name: 08-Pt2-04-Phú Sơn2 Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Hạnh operates a food stall/restaurant where she sells sweet rice. She is requesting a loan to purchase rice and pork so she can cook sticky rice for resale.

Hạnh is 42 years old and married with two children.

Hạnh is the group leader of the 08-PT2-04-Phú Sơn2 solidarity group, which consists of five members. She lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, an urban area in the Thanh Hoa province.

In 2011, Hạnh joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Hạnh has successfully repaid three loans from the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Hạnh has been involved in this business for eight years. The main hardship that Hạnh faces in her business is a lack of capital.

With her business profits, Hạnh hopes to ensure that her family will be healthy and happy and also to build a new house. She also hopes that her business will do well.

loans.use: to purchase rice and pork to cook sticky rice for resale.

loans.name: Carol

texts.en:
This is Carol. She previously accessed a 13,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan that she used to buy ingredients of bean curd pudding. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and in her personal, household and business expenditures. She has been running this business for seven years now.

She would like to apply for a new 18,000 PHP loan to buy ingredients for bean curd pudding. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain their daily needs and educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Carol dreams to give her children a good life and education and hopes that her business will grow bigger. She  meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her life and business every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for the ingredients of bean curd pudding.

loans.name: Teojerma

texts.en:
Teojerma is 52 years old and married with three children.

Teojerma works hard to provide for her family. She runs a broom-making business in the Philippines and requested a 25,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to buy materials for her broom-making business.

Teojerma has borrowed and repaid 17 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the broom-making business for six years and also earns an income from a piggery, handicraft making and a general store.

Teojerma aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To buy more materials for her broom-making business.

loans.name: Willy

texts.en:
Willy is a 21-year-old married man. He has a child who is one year old. He describes himself to be a social man.

Willy operates a motorcycle that he uses to provide transportation services. He has been involved in this business for one year. His business is located at a residential area and his primary customers are local residents. He describes his biggest business challenge to be insecurity within the area. 

Willy will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy motorcycle spare parts. 

His business goal is to improve his business within five years. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM. 

Willy also gets business income from his beauty salon which his wife works from.

loans.use: to buy motorcycle spare parts.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy poultry to sell

loans.name: Sadia Simon

texts.en:
Sadia Simon is a 30-year-old businesswoman who lives in Yei. She is married and has three children between the ages of three and eight.  All of them go to school.

Sadia Simon runs a fish selling business and has been in business for four years. She has no employees. Her major challenges include high prices in the market. She learned about Finance Sudan through other clients. She is taking a loan of 3,000 SSP in order to purchase more items like fish. Aside from this business, she has no other source of income.

In five years, Sadia Simon would like to expand her business.  Sadia Simon says she is happy for the loans given by Finance Sudan through the help of Kiva.

loans.use: to buy more items like fish.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is 35 years old and married with three children.  All three of her children are currently attending school.  She is a cold drinks seller in Kulanda Town in Bo, Sierra Leone. 

Lucy started her business to educate her children.  She works eleven hours per day, six days per week at her business.   Before her current business, she used to sell clothes.  Her biggest challenge at the business is that it can sometimes be slow. 

She requested this loan to purchase more inventory items, such as drinks, to expand her business.  One day, Lucy dreams of being an international businesswoman.   She will use the extra income to improve the life of her family and educate her children.  She appreciates your support.

loans.use: to purchase some more inventory items, such as drinks, to expand her business

loans.name: Hawanatu

texts.en:
This is 22-year-old Hawanatu from Kulanda Town, in Bo, Sierra Leone. She is married, with one child, aged two. Her husband is a moto-taxi driver and helps support the family.

Hawanatu was a student before, but her parents could not afford to pay her school fees, so she started her business of selling drinks and water by the road. She works six days per week and 12 hours per day at her business.   

She requested the loan from BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more drinks and water for her business. She hopes to use the extra income to improve her life and that of her family. 

In five years, she would like to own a house with her husband. She greatly appreciates your support!

loans.use: to buy more drinks and water to sell.

loans.name: Abibatu

texts.en:
This is 40-year-old Abibatu from Sierra Leone.  She lives in Torkpoi Town, Bo which is in the south of the country.  She is married with three children.  Two of the children are going to school. 

Abibatu owns a bar and lodging business where she works for 12 hours every day of the week.  She sells soft drinks, beer, stout, biscuits, sugar, soap and milk at her business. She wants to use the loan to purchase more stock for her business. She hopes that her business will continue to grow and help pay for her children’s education. She greatly appreciates your support!

loans.use: to purchase soft drinks, beer, stout, biscuits, sugar, soap and milk for her business

loans.name: Salamatu

texts.en:
Please meet Salamatu from Calabatown, Sierra Leone.  She is married and has three children, from ages 4 to 12 years old.

Salamatu operates a spare parts shop and works there from 10am to 6pm.  She started the business in 2005.  With this loan, she plans to purchase more inventory including engine oil, oil filters, and brake pads in order to expand her business.  In five years, she wants to be an importer of spare parts.  The greatest challenge in her business is the increase in prices of the inventory.  She greatly appreciates your support!

loans.use: to buy more inventory including engine oil, oil filters, and brake pads.

loans.name: Tenneh

texts.en: Tenneh is 34 years old and lives in Congo Town. She is married and has four children between 5 and 16 years old, who are in school and live at home.  For the past eight years Tenneh has been selling food ingredients, like bitter ball, pepper, rice and oil. She started this business with money given to her by her brother. Her favorite part about her business is that she makes more profit. She is requesting a loan to purchase more inventory for her business. She wants to become an international businesswoman, in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more items to resell in her business, like bitter ball, pepper, rice and oil

loans.name: Gabriel

texts.en:
Gabriel lives in the Mariakani area of Coast Province, Kenya. He owns a food stall and employs one other person. He mainly sells deep fried foods like potatoes, fish, etc. He learned about Milango through friends who invited him to the group and he joined with the aim of accessing credit to improve his business operations. His main challenges are competition and the affects of seasonal changes. 

Gabriel is applying for a loan of 41,850 Kenya shillings to buy food stock; e.g. potatoes, cassava, cooking fat etc. He will use the extra income from the loan to improve his living standards. His dream is to open a food cafe.

loans.use: To buy food stock; e.g. potatoes, cassava, cooking fat etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more clothes for sale.

loans.name: 08-Pt2-03-Phú Sơn2 Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Huệ has a service business washing motorcycles. She is requesting a loan to purchase equipment for washing motorbikes and to purchase fruit for resale.

Huệ is 43 years old and she is married with two children. Huệ is the group leader of the 08-PT2-03-Phú Sơn2 solidarity group, which consists of three members. Huệ lives with two dependents in Thanh Hoa city, an urban town in Thanh Hoa province.

In 2011, Huệ joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Huệ has successfully repaid three loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Huệ has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. The main hardship that Huệ faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Huệ hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, for her children to do well in school, and for her business to do well.

loans.use: to purchase equipment for washing motorbikes and to purchase fruit for resale.

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en:
Salvacion is 46 years old and has seven children. Salvacion is married and one of her children is in school.

Salvacion is in the agricultural business farming sugarcane in the Philippines. Salvacion requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy fertilizers and pay for laborers' salaries for her farms.

Salvacion has been farming sugarcane for 11 years now, and has borrowed 20 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Salvacion would like to save enough to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pay for laborer's salaries for her farms

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita is 51 years old and a widow with three children.

Anita works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 20,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like canned goods, soap, noodles, eggs, spices, etc.

Anita has borrowed and repaid nine loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for five years and also earns an income from farming sugarcane.

Anita aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like canned goods, soap, noodles, eggs, spices, etc.

loans.name: Felipe Adrian

texts.es:
El cliente Felipe vive en Guayaquil. El comenzó su negocio improvisando en la venta de empanadas, poco a poco fue mejorando su negocio. 
Debido a los ingresos que tenia decidió comprarse un carro usado para poder vender más sus empanadas, poco a poco fue vendiendo a mas clientes ya que podia movilizarce con mejor desempeño. En la actualidad está queriendo mejorar su negocio con un negocio estable en un local.

El realiza su trabajo solo, se levanta a las 4:00 de la mañana a preparar las coladas, el café y las empanadas de ahí sale a vender hasta las 13:00 de la tarde.

Está casado y su esposa es ama de casa, no tiene hijos. Con este préstamo quiere comprar harina, carnes, queso y avenas para hacer mas empanadas. Su sueño de poder incrementar el negocio y mejorar su hogar. Sobre todo su forma de vida.
texts.en:
Felipe lives in Guayaquil.  He started his business improvising selling turnovers and gradually improved his business.  With income he earned, he decided to buy a used vehicle to be able to sell more of his turnovers.  He gradually sold to more customers because he was now able to move from place to place better.  

He currently wants to improve his business by establishing it in a permanent, stable site.  He works alone rising at four in the morning to make the ‘coladas’ [traditional beverage made from oatmeal], coffee and turnovers that he then sets out to sell until one in the afternoon.  He’s married and his wife is a housewife; he has no children.  

He wants to use this loan to buy flour, meat, cheese and oatmeal to make more turnovers.  His dream is to be able to increase business and make improvements at home especially to his way of life.

loans.use: to buy flour, meat and oatmeal.

loans.name: 08-Pt3-03-Phú Sơn2 Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Hoa operates a food stall/restaurant selling soup. She is requesting a loan to purchase rice and pork to cook soup for resale. 

Hoa is 50 years old and she is married with three children. She is the leader of a five-member group, the 08-PT3-03-Phú Sơn2 solidarity group. She lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, an urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with three dependents.

In 2012, Hoa joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Hoa has successfully repaid two loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Hoa has been involved in this business for nine years. The main hardship that Hoa faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Hoa hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, to build a new house, and for her business to do well.

loans.use: to purchase rice and pork to cook soup for resale.

loans.name: Luciano

texts.es: Luciano de 35 años es un hombre de amplia capacidad laboral , esta casado con Lidia de 32 años y juntos tienen  3 hijos Liz, Frids y Lili a quienes dedican el fruto de su trabajo.Inicialmente dedicado a actividades agrícolas concernientes a la producción de cacao orgánico vio que era posible emprender y proceder como acopiador de barbasco.Lleva 10 años en el rubro y durante todo este tiempo a logrado consolidar su negocio como el principal sustento de su economía familiar.Trabajar con barbasco según comenta implica tener cierto cuidado puesto que son raíces que serán posteriormente usadas para insecticidas y repelentes naturales.Le agrada mucho su trabajo puesto que le permite facilitar el traslado de barbasco a los productores desde sus parcelas hasta su centro de acopio.A manera de tener un capital de reserva para la compra de barbasco desea contar con 2,000 nuevos soles para la compra de barbasco.Sus planes a largo plazo apuntan a la construcción del segundo piso de su vivienda para el futuro bienestar de sus hijos.
texts.en:
Luciano, 35, is a man with ample work capabilities.  He’s married to Lidia, 32, and they have three children together: Liz, Frids and Lili for whom they focus all their work efforts.  Initially he worked in agriculture growing organic cocoa beans and then saw the possibility of becoming a barbasco root supplier.  He’s been in this line of work for 10 years and in this time he’s succeeded in stabilizing his family’s economy.

He comments that one must be careful working with barbasco because they are roots that are used to make natural insecticide and repellent.   He enjoys his work very much because he’s able to transport the barbasco to producers from his parcels to the gathering center.  

In order to have capital in reserve to buy barbasco, he needs 2,000 new soles to buy barbasco.  His long-term plans point toward adding a second story to his house for his children’s future benefit.

loans.use: to buy barbasco roots.

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer is 43 years old and married with five children.

Jennifer works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 13,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like soap, sugar, milk, spices, etc.

Jennifer has borrowed and repaid five loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for two years and also earns an income from a restaurant.

Jennifer aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like soap, sugar, milk, spices, etc.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to purchase items to sell like shampoo, laundry detergent, canned goods, snack foods and other groceries for her general store.

Virginia has been in this business for 30 years. Virginia earns more income from selling fruits, vegetables, and root crops and hog raising.

Virginia successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her general store.

Virginia has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: To purchase items to sell like shampoo, laundry detergent, canned goods, snack foods and other groceries for her general store

loans.name: Rodelita

texts.en:
This is Rodelita. She previously accessed a 17,000 PHP loan that she used to buy bottles and ingredients for making dishwashing liquid. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and for their personal, household, and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for a 19,000 PHP loan to buy more bottles and ingredients needed to make dishwashing liquid. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain her family's daily needs and pay for her children's educational expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Rodelita dreams that her business will continue to grow and hopes that her family will live a good life. She meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week. It is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to buy bottles and ingredients for making dishwashing liquid

loans.name: Karla Patricia

texts.es:
La señora Karla patricia vive  en una comarca situado en la sierrita de Managua  en la parte sur de la capital, trabaja en una universidad en el área de limpieza entra a su trabajo a las 7am y termina de laboral a las 5 de la tarde, tiene tres niños.

Karla solicita a kiva por medio de ceprodel le sea financiado un crédito para compra de materiales de construcción como bloque cemento, ya que necesita hacerle una mejoras en su vivienda para darles mejor seguridad a sus pequeños y con este financiamiento es como lo puede hacer.
texts.en:
Karla Patricia lives in a district located in La Sierrita de Managua in the south part of the capital.  She works in the maintenance department at a university.  She starts work at 7am and ends at 5pm; she has three children.

Karla is asking Kiva through Ceprodel for a loan to buy building supplies like concrete blocks and cement because she needs to do some home improvements to provide more security for her little ones and the loan will make it possible for her to do so.

loans.use: to buy concrete blocks, cement and rebar.

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.es:
Magdalena es viuda, tiene tres hijas de las cuales  dos ya son independientes y la última vive con ella en la zona de alto san pedro de la ciudad de La Paz; Magdalena se dedica a la elaboración de artesanías; es jubilada y percibe una renta con la cual se mantiene y mantiene a su familia. Su negocio de las artesanías le ayuda con sus ingresos.

Ella solicita el crédito para pagar los trámites de su casa, ya que se quedó viuda muy joven y no pudo poner en orden la declatoria de herederos.

El sueño de Magdalena fue poder sacar profesionales a sus hijas lo cual ya se realizó en las dos hijas mayores, solo le falta con la hija menor, con lo cual su sueño estaría cumplido.
texts.en:
Magdalena is a widow and has three daughters; two of them are independent and the youngest still lives with her in the city of La Paz’s Alto San Pedro zone.  Magdalena works making crafts.  She’s retired and earns a pension that supports her and her family.  Her crafts business helps with income.  

She requests the loan to pay for some paperwork related to her house since she was widowed very young and was unable to put her inheritance in order.  Magdalena’s dream is to see her daughters become professionals which she’s already accomplished with her two oldest daughters; only the youngest remains for her dream to be complete.

loans.use: to pay for legal transactions related to her house.

loans.name: 04.10.06.nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Thu works in agriculture, farming poultry and cattle. She is requesting a loan to purchase chickens and ducks to raise for resale. Thu is 61 years old and she is married with one child. She is the leader of a 3-member group, the 04.10.06.Nam Ngạn solidarity group. She lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, an urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with no dependents. Her child is grown up.

In 2011, Thu joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her  business. Thu has successfully repaid 3 loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Thu has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. The main hardship that Thu faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Thu hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, to build a new house, and for her business to do well.

loans.use: to purchase chickens and ducks to raise for resale

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Lolita  works hard to support her family. She has a gasoline retailing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from food vending.  Lolita is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to purchase additional gallons of gasoline to sell for her gasoline retailing business.

Lolita  has been sustaining her business activities through her past 16 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional gallons of gasoline to sell

loans.name: 04.10.01.nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Thanh operates a food stall selling fruit. She is requesting a loan to purchase fruit for resale.

Thanh is 57 years old and she is married with two children. She is the group leader of the 04.10.01.Nam Ngạn solidarity group, which consists of three members. She lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, an urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with no dependents. Her children are grown up.

In 2009, Thanh joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her  business. Thanh has successfully repaid four loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Thanh has been involved in this business for five years. One of the most critical business difficulties that concerns her is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Thanh hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, to build a new house, and for her business to do well.

loans.use: to purchase fruit for resale

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa works hard to support her family. Marissa is married and has a business buying and selling dried fish in the Philippines.

Marissa requested a PHP 28,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional boxes of dried fish to sell.

Marissa has been in this business for 20 years now.

In the future, Marissa would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional boxes of dried fish to sell

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Delia works hard to support her family. She has a ready-to-wear business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from pig fattening. Delia is borrowing PHP 24,000 through NWTF to buy more stock like belts, wallets, watches, etc. to sell for her business.

Delia has been sustaining her business activities through her past 19 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more stock like belts, wallets, watches, etc. to sell
